awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Assessing the Potential Causes of a Second Epidemiological Transition
awd_abstract_narration:
The work of anthropologists, demographers, and other social scientists contributes to understanding the factors that influence health and well-being. While public health researchers focus on identifying the immediate biological causes of disease, social scientists also step back to examine the larger cultural, social, economic, and political context that mediates people's disease exposure and susceptibility. Historically, such factors have produced major shifts in mortality patterns and health outcomes. One such transition is associated with the rise of epidemic infectious diseases that occurred in the wake of the rise of a sedentary, agricultural way of life, millennia ago. More recently, industrialization saw a decline in infectious diseases and major reductions in infant and childhood mortality. This second transition has now been followed by a third, when non-communicable diseases replaced infectious ones as the major cause of human adult mortality. Interestingly, however, the factors underlying these shifts are not clear. Was it improvement in personal hygiene and general sanitary conditions? Advances in medical science? Economic and political stability? A variety of scenarios and factors have been proposed. The research supported by this award takes advantage of a unique opportunity to determine the most influential of these many potential drivers by looking at a case of delayed transition in the 20th. century for which there are a number of untapped data sources.

With the guidance of University of Missouri anthropologist, Dr. Lisa Sattenspiel, co-PI and doctoral student Dana M. Schmidt, will examine the patterns of health and mortality corresponding to 20th century industrialization in Newfoundland and Labrador. She will focus on specific drivers known to be of some importance in the region at this time, including access to health care, improvements in sanitation, nutritional programs, and overall improvements in socioeconomic status although with variation in urban and rural locales. Research questions include:  To what extent do improvements in sanitation reduce infectious disease prevalence or mortality? How effective were quarantines at preventing disease? Does incentivized migration from rural to urban areas improve living standards and have positive impacts on health? Addressing questions of this nature in a historical population has practical implications for the implementation of social policies and assessing their efficacy at improving health and reducing disparity in current populations. The island of Newfoundland is an ideal study location to address these topics because the island underwent significant political changes as it went from a struggling British Colony to self-governing Dominion to Canadian province during the first half of the 20th century. Such changes produced new economic and social climates for the population with concomitant demographic and health effects. The researchers will collect data from vital statistics records, death registers, and archival resources from the Provincial Archives of Newfoundland and Labrador, including newspaper articles, government papers regarding health policy and reform, and diaries. These data will allow the researchers to assess the timing of the transition, its pace, and the driving factors for observed health changes. Findings from this research will contribute to understanding epidemiological transitions in non-industrial and industrializing nations. By examining the implementation of social policies and their efficacy at improving health and reducing disparity in this case with its abundant data sources, conclusions can be drawn that will be of interest to scholars studying any context where the relation between policy and population health and wellbeing is of concern.

por.por_cntn:
The co-PI Dana Schmidt has completed research for her dissertation project “Assessing the Potential Causes of a Second Epidemiological Transition”, supported by the National Science Foundation Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant with PI Dr. Lisa Sattenspiel. During the funding period, she spent a total of four months conducting archival research in Newfoundland and Labrador, Canada. Most of the research was conducted in the capital of St. John’s at The Rooms Provincial Archives of Newfoundland and Labrador and The Centre for Newfoundland Studies at Memorial University, with brief visits to collections in the small coastal towns of Bonavista and Twillingate. 

 

The goal of the project was to collect vital statistics records and death registers to examine the patterns of health and mortality on the island during the early to mid-20thcentury. Prior research on the epidemiologic transition suggested that significant improvements in health and mortality patterns in Western nations occurred in tandem with late 18thand early 19thcentury industrialization, and that major shifts in life expectancy and disease outcomes in Newfoundland and Labrador occurred much later due to a variety of social, political, and economic factors. Additional archival resources including newspaper articles, government papers regarding health policy and reform, and diaries provided context to explain these socioeconomic and political factors more thoroughly. Access to health care, advances in sanitation, nutritional programs, and better socioeconomic conditions each contributed to improvements in morbidity and mortality. Using archival materials, theresearch also examined health disparities between urban and rural locales and how poverty and location influence disease and mortality outcomes, an issue of interest to anthropologists, other social scientists, and health researchers working with both historical and modern populations. 

 

While the specific socioeconomic and political circumstances that shaped Newfoundland’s health and mortality patterns are unique to the island, our findings can provide insight into epidemiologic transitions in modern developing nations. Epidemiologic transition theory posits that major changes in human behavior including social organization and subsistence strategies contribute to significant shifts in disease patterns. During the time period examined, Newfoundland went from a self-governing dominion to a British crown colony, representing a period of major social reform, and later became a Canadian province in 1949. This political upheaval had an impact on residents’ lifestyles and daily activities. Prior to 1949, the economy diversified in the major port city of St. John’s, shifting away from a reliance of the struggling fishing industry and credit-based pay, enhancing economic opportunity. Simultaneously, more funds were invested in public works, public health, and medical initiatives in the city and surrounding areas. Infant mortality, especially from infectious diseases declined drastically in urban St. John’s during this time, while it remained high in rural Newfoundland until after 1949 when the Canadian government initiated many rural health programs with varying degrees of success. As we examine this period of major political change and social reform in Newfoundland we have observed the ways that specific social policies were implemented and the resulting health outcomes including reduction in health disparities. A similar framework can be applied to studying mortality transitions in modern developing nations and the impacts of policy on population health and well being, especially in nations experiencing social changes or new economic opportunities. 

 

While the findings of the research are of interest within the academic community, the researchers’ transcription of death records resulting from this research may be of personal interest to the descendants of early 20th century Newfoundlanders. Copies of the database of transcribed death records and the dissertation itself will be supplied to the Centre for Newfoundland Studies and The Rooms Provincial Archives upon defense of the dissertation project within the next calendar year. This will make some of these records more readily accessible than the current microfilm or non-lendable book formats that are currently available. Finally, this project contributed to the training of a female graduate student in anthropological demography, techniques involved in archival research, and other qualitative and quantitative analytical procedures.
